Picbreeder usage is fairly consistent over the long term with
occasional sp=
ikes caused by modest media exposure.   We have a few
regulars who tend to =
produce a number of pictures in bursts and then
return a few days or weeks =
later, and we also have a steady stream of
new people who tend to come in, =
publish a few pictures, and then never
publish anything again.  In terms of=
 actual numbers, maybe about 10-25
pictures are published each day.  There =
are almost 6,000 total
published images after 1.5 years, so that gives you =
a sense of
activity overall.  Daily activity has increased over that time, =
but
not by that much.

Another interesting thing is that many more people v=
isit and browse
the site than actually publish something.  Another chunk of=
 visitors
save images privately but never publish them publicly (we can see=
 how
many images are saved that are not published).  It seems many people
t=
ake public publishing seriously.

Branching does seem to lead to better ima=
ges in people's opinion. 
Only 1.87% of the 482 top-rated images were evolv=
ed within 20
generations.  So that would suggest that some level of complex=
ity is
correlated to quality.  However, it is also evident that some
relati=
vely simple pictures are quite appealing.  You can now look at
complexity l=
evels (in terms of nodes and connections) in the detailed
view.  It is clea=
r that some of the top-rated images are relatively
the most complex.  For e=
xample this "planet" has almost 500
connections: http://picbreeder.org/sear=
ch/showgenome.php?sid=3D5776

I think what people appreciate is (1) being a=
ble to recognize the
image as something familiar, (2) complexity, (3) regul=
arity. 
Interestingly, 2 and 3 are in conflict, which means you don't want =
too
much of either (e.g. total irregularity means high complexity).  So I
w=
ould say that there is some minimum level of complexity when things
become =
compelling, and that beyond that other factors come into play.
 Still, we m=
ay see a new order of complexity evolve if we wait long
enough that is even=
 more impressive.

About the custom products: This option is not popular at=
 all.  People
are simply not buying products based on these images.  That's=
 okay to
me because I like to show people the custom products option more
b=
ecause of the *ideas* it generates rather than to make money: People
start =
to see the commercial potential of interactive evolution.  But
the use of t=
he option itself has been disappointing so far.  We do not
know why that is=
.  Perhaps people don't realize it's available, or
perhaps they are concern=
ed with quality like you.  Or maybe they are
waiting for the holidays :)  B=
ut I do think it's important to think
about what it would take to get peopl=
e to buy evolved products.

I did buy a shirt and a mug myself with Picbree=
der images on them
before we made the custom products option available to s=
ee what it
would be like.  The quality was good in my opinion.  Zazzle gets=

ultra-high-resolution versions of the images (because CPPNs are in
effect =
infinite resolution we can send them to Zazzle at any
resolution) so they c=
ome out nice.  The images were properly
integrated with the materials and h=
aven't faded.  I am thinking of
buying other stuff too.

ken

plexity and some

m interested to know

ged in these types of very cool,
